channel.title: State-Policy Think-Tank Digest
channel.description: Latest posts from free-market policy institutes across the U.S.

item.title: [Mspolicy] If You Want Parent Power, Only HB2 Will Do
item.description:
Over the past few years, Mississippi lawmakers have passed some critical conservative reforms. Last year, Mississippi became the first state in America to legislate to eliminate the income tax in 40 years.  In 2022, we implemented flat tax reform.  A few years before that, we passed important labor market reforms.  In 2024, we reformed school funding […]

The post If You Want Parent Power, Only HB2 Will Do appeared first on Mississippi Center for Public Policy.

item.title: [Rifreedom] MEDIA RELEASE: Center Launches Petition Calling for Affordable Energy Policies
item.description:
The Rhode Island Center for Freedom & Prosperity today announced that it has launched an online petition drive calling for policymakers to support a fundamental pivot away from our state's current energy strategy, which will lead to staggeringly high electricity prices and potentially dangerous blackouts.

The post MEDIA RELEASE: Center Launches Petition Calling for Affordable Energy Policies appeared first on RI Center for Freedom and Prosperity.

item.description:
by Aiden DeMarsey, NJPI Jr. Fellow   Governor Mikie Sherrill, sworn into office last week, enters her term with a […]

The post A New Governor Takes Office. Will She Deliver on Education? first appeared on New Jersey Policy Institute.

item.title: [Jbartlett] New housing permits are highest since 2006, but single-family homes lag
item.description:
New Hampshire towns and cities are permitting more residential housing units than they have in years, which is great news. But the new units are skewed heavily toward rentals, suggesting that local restrictions on small, single-family homes remain a significant barrier. Local governments issued permits for 5,822 new housing units in 2024, the highest number […]

The post New housing permits are highest since 2006, but single-family homes lag appeared first on THE JOSIAH BARTLETT CENTER FOR PUBLIC POLICY.

item.title: [Freedomfoundationofminnesota] The Denial of Distinctions
item.description:
The Denial of Distinctions By Abe Greenwald Yesterday, I wrote about the return of American disorder in the form of mobs that obstruct ICE raids. Part of what makes anti-ICE/open-border activism so strange is that it attacks the most fundamental aspect of what it means to be a country: its physical boundaries. When leftists repeat, […]

The post The Denial of Distinctions appeared first on Freedom Foundation of Minnesota.

item.description: Today, we released the latest installment of the Beacon Poll, a statewide survey of 1,200 Tennessee voters featuring questions about voters’ views on property taxes, the federal school choice tax credit included in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, and political approval ratings at the state and federal level, and more. Tennesseans continue to prioritize key...

item.title: [Cardinalinstitute] Op-Ed: Hospitals Collect Tax Breaks. West Virginians Collect Medical Debt.
item.description:
To many West Virginians, healthcare continues to be a burden more than a lifeline as roughly 180,000 residents, or 13.3% of adults, now facing some sort of  medical debt. This is well above the national average of 8.6% and, even worse, nearly one in four of these residents in rural Appalachia have medical debt in […]

The post Op-Ed: Hospitals Collect Tax Breaks. West Virginians Collect Medical Debt. appeared first on Cardinal Institute.

item.title: [Mainepolicy] Why Portland’s Suggested Statewide Eviction Moratorium Would Hurt Maine’s Housing Market
item.description:
Portland city officials are urging Gov. Janet Mills to impose a 60-day statewide eviction moratorium in response to “fear and instability” that they are linking to federal immigration enforcement. While the resolution is framed as an emergency measure that they are claiming is only meant to protect “vulnerable residents,” such a moratorium risks repeating a […]

The post Why Portland’s Suggested Statewide Eviction Moratorium Would Hurt Maine’s Housing Market appeared first on Maine Policy Institute.

item.title: [Freedomfoundationofminnesota] Tim Pawlenty: The Crisis Will Subside in Minnesota, but Trust Will Need to be Rebuilt
item.description:
We’ll all be part of that task. Here’s where efforts could be focused. By Tim Pawlenty For the Star Tribune It’s been said that trust is the glue that holds relationships together. That may well explain why recent events in Minnesota have stretched our relationship with government to the breaking point. Fraudsters stole a ton […]

item.title: [Alabamapolicy] The Numbers Don’t Lie: The CHOOSE Act is Empowering Alabama’s Families
item.description:
For decades, the Alabama Policy Institute has championed a simple, powerful idea: every child in Alabama deserves a high-quality education, regardless of their zip code or their size of their parents’ bank account. With the passage and implementation of the CHOOSE Act, that vision is finally becoming a reality.

The post The Numbers Don’t Lie: The CHOOSE Act is Empowering Alabama’s Families appeared first on Alabama Policy Institute.

item.title: [Freedomfoundationofminnesota] 312 Out of More than 3 Million Votes
item.description:
Federal prosecutors are closing in on prosecuting more than 100 Minnesotans for rampant fraud in several social service programs designed to serve children and low-income residents. By the time the US Attorney’s office is done investigating, charging, convicting, and sentencing these felons, this unchecked fraud will significantly increase Minnesota’s prison population. But there’s one other […]

The post 312 Out of More than 3 Million Votes appeared first on Freedom Foundation of Minnesota.

item.title: [Rifreedom] TESTIMONY: Senate Commission to Study the Successful Implementation of the Act on Climate
item.description:
In this powerful testimony, Mike Stenhouse, CEO of the RI Center for Freedom & Prosperity, explains why energy policy—not taxes, not housing, not government services—is the single most important determinant of Rhode Island’s future prosperity or poverty. Whether one believes in climate change or not, the economic consequences of the Act on Climate are unavoidable.

The post TESTIMONY: Senate Commission to Study the Successful Implementation of the Act on Climate appeared first on RI Center for Freedom and Prosperity.

item.title: [Mainepolicy] Governor Mills’ Supplemental Budget Abandons Fiscal Discipline, Sets Maine Up for Higher Costs
item.description:
Governor Janet Mills’ FY 2026 supplemental budget marks a clear break from the fiscal restraint her administration often claimed to practice. Rather than using Maine’s strong revenue growth to stabilize taxpayers after years of tax increases and inflation, the proposal dramatically expands spending, broadens emergency powers, and doubles down on distortionary tax policy choices that […]

item.title: [Alabamapolicy] Alabama Senate unanimously passes App Store Accountability Act
item.description:
The App Store Accountability Act passed the Alabama Senate with a unanimous vote on Feb. 5. The bill is focused on online safety for children and teens by requiring parental approval for kids to download apps from the App Store.

item.title: [Riograndefoundation] RGF talks to KOAT TV about roads
item.description:
SB 2 has passed which means that the road issue has been “put to bed” for the time being. The bill which has been signed by the Gov. includes: $1.5 billion in new road spending via a bond (debt) package. This also includes: A 35% increase in the weight-distance tax on trucks A 25% increase […]

item.title: [Pioneerinstitute] Domestic Outmigration is Hollowing Out Massachusetts’ Workforce and Economy
item.description:
From April 2020 through July 2025, Massachusetts experienced a net loss of approximately 182,000 residents to domestic outmigration — the equivalent of losing one-and-a-half Cambridges. While a recent surge in international immigration temporarily boosted labor force numbers, new research from Pioneer Institute shows that underlying demographic, workforce, and economic challenges continue to threaten the Commonwealth’s long-term competitiveness. 

The post Domestic Outmigration is Hollowing Out Massachusetts’ Workforce and Economy  appeared first on Pioneer Institute.

item.title: [Kansaspolicy] Bipartisan electoral politics stand in the way of property tax relief
item.description: Kansas homeowners aren’t just facing higher property taxes — they’re facing unaffordable assessed valuation increases that make it impossible to budget for life essentials or stay in their homes. Property tax is the #1 affordability issue facing many Kansans, but nothing may be done about it – again – because electoral politics is the #1 […]

item.title: [Mainepolicy] An Open Letter to Maine’s Legislature: Stop Advancing a Bill You Know is Unconstitutional
item.description:
Last June, Maine Policy Institute urged Governor Janet Mills to veto LD 1666, a bill expanding ranked-choice voting (RCV) to elections for governor, state senator, and state representative. That request was grounded in clear constitutional text, the Maine Supreme Judicial Court’s 2017 advisory opinion, and Governor Mills’ own legal analysis as Attorney General. Since then, […]

item.description:

item.title: [Rifreedom] Center Launches K-12 Student Video Contest to Celebrate America’s 250th Birthday #America250RI
item.description:
In recognition of President's Day and George Washington's upcoming birthday, the RI Center for Freedom & Prosperity today launched a video contest encouraging K-12 students to create a video about why they are proud to celebrate America's semiquincentennial, commemorating the 250th Anniversary of the US Declaration of Independence.

item.title: [Platteinstitute] Research Note: Updates in Regulatory Restraint
item.description:
In recent years, states across the country have taken renewed interest in reviewing longstanding and often outdated regulatory frameworks. Many legislatures are reassessing rules that may constrain economic growth, aiming to reduce regulatory accumulation and increase legislative oversight of unelected agencies. Although each state varies in its approach, a common goal has emerged: limiting high-cost...

The post Research Note: Updates in Regulatory Restraint appeared first on Platte Institute.

item.title: [Will Law] WILL Supports Teacher Bill of Rights
item.description:
Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty (WILL) supports the Teacher Bill of Rights, AB 614 / SB 611, introduced by Representative Goeben and Senator Cabral-Guevara. The legislation clarifies and strengthens teachers’ authority to maintain order in the classroom, protects teachers from retaliation when they enforce classroom rules or respond to disruptive or violent behavior, and ensures transparency and accountability when serious behavior incidents occur at school.

The post WILL Supports Teacher Bill of Rights appeared first on Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty.

item.title: [Jbartlett] Legislators look at local zoning rules blocking education, child care & home businesses
item.description:
Local land use regulations do more than severely restrict the size, shape, design and placement of homes, creating scarcity and driving up prices. Local governments exist primarily for the purpose of keeping the peace, and Americans […]

item.title: [Mspolicy] New Certificate of Need Law – A Small Free Market Win
item.description:
A small win for freedom in Mississippi!  Governor Tate Reeves recently signed HB3, a law that reforms the state’s Certificate of Need (CON) rules.  CON is basically a government approval process healthcare providers (like hospitals) must go through before they can add certain services, build new facilities, buy expensive equipment, or make big expansions. HB3 […]

item.title: [Texaspolicy] Assessing Tax Trends in the City of Austin
item.description:
Does history suggest that property taxes are too high in the city of Austin? And, if so, have local decision-makers actively helped or hurt the situation?   To help answer these questions, let’s review the city’s 2024 Annual Comprehensive Financial Report (ACFR) and gather four types of data—i.e., tax levies, local population, total tax rates, and taxable values—over a 10-year time horizon. Using these audited estimates, we can gauge the growth of government (i.e., tax levy trends), assess its reasonability...

item.title: [Thomasjeffersoninst] The Death of Fair Representation: Every Partisan-Drawn Map is an Insult, but Virginia’s is the Most Insulting
item.description:

The other is political temptation. Right now, Virginia stands at the crossroads between the two. On April 21st the voters will decide which way we turn.  Using current congressional delegation data and 2024 presidential vote totals, we can measure fairness in a straightforward way: compare a party’s statewide vote share in the last Presidential […]

item.title: [Itrfoundation] First in the nation: How Iowa can lead the country in welfare reform
item.description:
Key takeaways: Download a PDF of the full report. Iowa’s welfare system is at a crossroads. What were once temporary safety-net programs designed to protect the truly vulnerable have steadily expanded into sprawling systems that now touch nearly every corner of state government—and consume an ever-growing share of taxpayer resources. Nowhere is this more evident than in Medicaid and food […]

The post First in the nation: How Iowa can lead the country in welfare reform appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Itrfoundation] Iowa’s Welfare System Is Broken—and Now There’s a Path to Fix It
item.description:
Medicaid has become Iowa’s largest welfare program, enrolling nearly one in five residents and consuming about one-quarter of the state budget, with rapid growth since the 2014 expansion. Rising welfare costs are straining taxpayers and crowding out core priorities, while contributing to workforce challenges and long-term dependency. Federal reforms create an opportunity for Iowa to lead, by enforcing work requirements, tightening eligibility, limiting loopholes, and restoring accountability. To better understand the scope and trajectory of Iowa’s welfare system, ITR Foundation commissioned a comprehensive report outlining both the challenges and the path forward. This article offers the highlights of that analysis.  For readers seeking a deeper dive,  the full report is accessible in the links above.

The post Iowa’s Welfare System Is Broken—and Now There’s a Path to Fix It appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Itrfoundation] Iowa can do more to reduce workforce barriers
item.description:
The need for more qualified workers is a bipartisan issue in Iowa. Regardless of a rural or urban setting, workforce is still a concern for many employers and communities. State policymakers have been responsive to this concern, and they have actively been easing regulatory burdens in recent years. This includes reducing barriers to employment and ensuring that unnecessary roadblocks do not deter individuals from securing meaningful work.

The post Iowa can do more to reduce workforce barriers appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Texaspolicy] Assessing Tax Trends in the City of Arlington
item.description:
Does history suggest that property taxes are too high in the city of Arlington? And, if so, have local decision-makers actively helped or hurt the situation?   To help answer these questions, let’s review the city’s 2024 Annual Comprehensive Financial Report (ACFR) and gather four types of data—i.e., tax levies, local population, total tax rates, and taxable values—over a 10-year time horizon. Using these audited estimates, we can gauge the growth of government (i.e., tax levy trends), assess its reasonability...

item.title: [Mountainstatespolicy] U.S. Supreme Court upholds the exclusive taxing power of Congress
item.description: Whether tariff tax increases are good or bad economic policy, the fact remains that tax increases should be introduced, debated, and voted on by Congress. Major economic policies of any kind should not be imposed by one person unilaterally. This decision by the U.S. Supreme Court upholds and affirms that important check and balance of our republic.

item.title: [Thomasjeffersoninst] Supreme Court Restores the Rule of Law and, for a Moment, Increased Economic Freedom
item.description:
The Supreme Court’s decision in Learning Resources v. Trump is a landmark reaffirmation of one of the Constitution’s most fundamental principles: the power to tax belongs to Congress alone. Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution explicitly vests in the legislative branch the authority “to lay and collect Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises.” Tariffs are taxes, and the Court […]

The post Supreme Court Restores the Rule of Law and, for a Moment, Increased Economic Freedom appeared first on Thomas Jefferson Institute for Public Policy.
